greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array A(1,k) = A019565(k), A(n,k) = A065642(A(n-1,k)), read by descending antidiagonals.
comment: A permutation of the natural numbers > 1.
Otherwise like array A284311, but the columns come in different order.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..120; the first 15 antidiagonals of array
example: The top left 12x6 corner of the array:
mathematica: a065642[n_] := Module[{k}, If[n == 1, Return[1], k = n + 1; While[ EulerPhi[k]/k != EulerPhi[n]/n, k++]]; k];
Table[A[n - k + 1, k], {n, 1, 10}, {k, n, 1, -1}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 17 2019 *)
program: (define (A285321bi row col) (if (= 1 row) (A019565 col) (A065642 (A285321bi (- row 1) col))))
def a019565(n): return reduce(mul, (prime(i+1) for i, v in enumerate(bin(n)[:1:-1]) if v == '1')) if n > 0 else 1 # This function from _Chai Wah Wu_
def a007947(n): return 1 if n<2 else reduce(mul, primefactors(n))
def A(n, k): return a019565(k) if n==1 else a065642(A(n - 1, k))
for n in range(1, 11): print([A(k, n - k + 1) for k in range(1, n + 1)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Apr 18 2017
xref: Cf. A008479 (index of the row where n is located), A087207 (of the column).
Cf. arrays A284311, A285325, also A285332.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Apr 17 2017
